study.title: Occurrence of Post-Surgical Wound Infections, Bacterial Isolates, and their Susceptibility to Commonly Used Antibiotics at Kenyatta National Hospital, Kenya
study.journal: International Journal of Science and Research (IJSR)

design.inclusion_criteria_text: Adult (>18 years), had undergone surgery at KNH, had an identifiable superficial SSI with signs: purulent exudate, swelling, erythema, pain, local temperature, peri wound cellulitis or surgeon’s diagnosis of infection after the surgical period, and consented.
design.exclusion_criteria_text: Immunocompromised patients and those on long term treatment with corticosteroids.

eligibility.population: Adult patients (>18 years) admitted at the surgical ward after undergoing surgery at KNH with superficial SSI.
eligibility.intervention: Not specified; study focused on occurrence and susceptibility, not intervention.
eligibility.timeframe_years: Not explicitly stated; study conducted prior to August 2022.

populations.description: All adult patients (>18 years) admitted at the surgical ward after surgery at KNH with superficial SSI.

provenance.text_snippet: This was a cross sectional study conducted at the Kenyatta National hospital (KNH) using a population sample of 62 male and female adult patients admitted at the surgical ward after undergoing surgery.

definitions.resistance_definition_text: Resistance determined by Kirby Bauer disk diffusion method; MRSA defined by Oxacillin disc; VRE by Vancomycin resistance.
definitions.outcome_definitions_text: SSI defined as superficial infection with purulent exudate, swelling, erythema, pain, local temperature, peri wound cellulitis or surgeon’s diagnosis.

lab_methods.specimen_collection_method: Pus from surgical wounds collected using sterile cotton swabs and transported to laboratory.
lab_methods.culture_method: Inoculation onto blood agar and MacConkey plates; incubation under CO2 and aerobic conditions.
lab_methods.QC_measures: Quality control with S. aureus ATCC 25923, E. coli ATCC 25922, P. aeruginosa ATCC 27853.
lab_methods.organism_identification_method: Colonial morphology, Gram stain, conventional biochemical tests, API 20E for Gram-negatives.
lab_methods.contamination_handling: Plates classified as mixed or pure growth.

ssi_incidence.notes: SSI defined as superficial infection; 45/62 samples had bacterial growth.

provenance.text_snippet: Out of the 62 pus samples that were collected, bacterial isolates were recovered from seven in ten samples (n=45, 72.6%)

amr_proportions.notes: 91.7% resistance; n_resistant derived from percent and n_tested.

provenance.text_snippet: E. coli showed high resistance to ceftriaxone (91.7%).

amr_proportions.notes: 66.7% resistance; n_resistant derived from percent and n_tested.

provenance.text_snippet: Proteus spp showed high resistance to Ceftazidime and Ceftriazone (66.7%).

amr_proportions.notes: 56.3% MRSA; n_resistant derived from percent and n_tested.

provenance.section_heading: Antibiotics susceptibility pattern of Gram-positive Isolates
provenance.text_snippet: In cases of Staphylococcusaureus 56.3% of the isolates were found resistant to Methicillin (Oxacillin)

amr_proportions.notes: 75% resistance; n_resistant derived from percent and n_tested.

provenance.section_heading: Antibiotics susceptibility pattern of Gram-positive Isolates
provenance.text_snippet: 3 of the isolates were Vancomycin (75%) resistant

codes.summary: SSI incidence among surgical patients at KNH was high, with 72.6% of samples showing bacterial growth.

evidence_quotes.quote: Out of the 62 pus samples that were collected, bacterial isolates were recovered from seven in ten samples (n=45, 72.6%)

provenance.text_snippet: Out of the 62 pus samples that were collected, bacterial isolates were recovered from seven in ten samples (n=45, 72.6%)

codes.subtheme: resistance patterns and rates by pathogen/antibiotic
codes.summary: High rates of resistance were observed among Gram-negative and Gram-positive isolates, including 91.7% ceftriaxone resistance in E. coli and 56.3% MRSA among S. aureus.

evidence_quotes.quote: E. coli showed high resistance to ceftriaxone (91.7%).
In cases of Staphylococcusaureus 56.3% of the isolates were found resistant to Methicillin (Oxacillin)
evidence_quotes.section: Antibiotics susceptibility pattern of Gram-positive Isolates

provenance.text_snippet: E. coli showed high resistance to ceftriaxone (91.7%).

codes.summary: Overuse and misuse of antibiotics, including prophylactic use, may contribute to high resistance rates observed.

evidence_quotes.quote: Resistance to Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin could be explained by they having been used as prophylaxis preoperatively hence increasing their use in patients. Over-use of antibiotics has been shown to contributes to organisms developing resistance.

provenance.text_snippet: Resistance to Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin could be explained by they having been used as prophylaxis preoperatively hence increasing their use in patients.

codes.summary: The study recommends infection control measures and surveillance to minimize the incidence of SSIs and spread of resistant isolates.

evidence_quotes.quote: Control and prevention measures should be put into place as strategy to minimize the incidence of SSIs and the spread of resistance isolates.
There is need for continuous surveillance genotypic characterization of clinical isolates and their antimicrobial susceptibility patterns.

provenance.text_snippet: Control and prevention measures should be put into place as strategy to minimize the incidence of SSIs and the spread of resistance isolates.

codes.summary: The study highlights the need for national surveillance of antibiotic resistant organisms and further research including anaerobic cultures.

evidence_quotes.quote: There is need to develop National surveillance of antibiotic resistant organisms.
Future studies should be extended to include cultures under anaerobic conditions to establish presence of other bacteria that require such environment for growth.

provenance.text_snippet: There is need to develop National surveillance of antibiotic resistant organisms.

notes_flags.detail: n_resistant for AMR outcomes calculated from percent and n_tested for E. coli, Proteus spp., S. aureus, and E. faecalis.

provenance.text_snippet: E. coli showed high resistance to ceftriaxone (91.7%).

notes_flags.detail: No data on mortality, morbidity, reoperations, readmissions, length of stay, costs, or risk factors effects.

provenance.text_snippet: had an identifiable superficial SSI with the following signs

provenance_index.text_snippet: This was a cross sectional study conducted at the Kenyatta National hospital (KNH) using a population sample of 62 male and female adult patients admitted at the surgical ward after undergoing surgery.
Out of the 62 pus samples that were collected, bacterial isolates were recovered from seven in ten samples (n=45, 72.6%)
E. coli showed high resistance to ceftriaxone (91.7%).

provenance_index.section_heading: Antibiotics susceptibility pattern of Gram-positive Isolates
provenance_index.text_snippet: In cases of Staphylococcusaureus 56.3% of the isolates were found resistant to Methicillin (Oxacillin)
Resistance to Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin could be explained by they having been used as prophylaxis preoperatively hence increasing their use in patients.
Control and prevention measures should be put into place as strategy to minimize the incidence of SSIs and the spread of resistance isolates.
There is need to develop National surveillance of antibiotic resistant organisms.
